document.docAuthor: Rheims, Cristina A. & Brescovit, Antonio D.
document.docTitle: Scytodes tyaia Rheims & Brescovit, 2009, new species
document.masterDocTitle: New additions to the Brazilian fauna of the genus Scytodes Latreille (Araneae: Scytodidae) with emphasis on the Atlantic Forest species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New additions to the Brazilian fauna of the genus Scytodes Latreille (Araneae: Scytodidae) with emphasis on the Atlantic Forest species

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURES 62 – 73. 62 – 67. Scytodes bonito n. sp. 62. Male habitus, dorsal; 63 – 65. Left male palp (63 prolateral, 64 retrolateral, 65 detail of distal region, dorsal). 66 – 67. Female epigynum (66 ventral, 67 dorsal). 68 – 73. Scytodes tyaia n. sp. 68. Male habitus, dorsal; 69 – 73 Left male palp (69 prolateral, 70 retrolateral, 71 detail of distal region, dorsal). 72 – 67. Female epigynum (66 ventral, 67 dorsal) (K = keel; SLP = serrated laminar process; SP = sclerotized process). Scale lines: 0.5 mm.

Etymology . The specific name is a noun in apposition taken from the Brazilian Tupi Indian language that means claw and refers to the very strong and curved sclerotized process in the distal region of the male palpal bulb.

Diagnosis . Males of
Scytodes tyaia
n.sp. are distinguished from those of the remaining Neotropical
Scytodes
by the large and strong retrolateral sclerotized process (
Figs. 70–71
). The females are distinguished by rounded spermathecae anterior to widely separated, rounded hyaline pockets with triangular sclerotized projection adjacent to large median membranous area (
Fig. 73
).
Variation . Ten males: total length 3.5–4.5 ; carapace 1.9–2.3 ; femur I 4.1–5.4 ; bulb 0.44–0.64 . Ten females: total length: 4.2 –6.0; carapace 2.0– 2.9 ; femur I 2.6–3.6 .
Distribution . Atlantic Forest. Known from the states of Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo.
